newsitem.title: RUSSIA: SOCCER-CLOSE RUSSIAN TITLE RACE REACHES CLIMAX.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-CLOSE RUSSIAN TITLE RACE REACHES CLIMAX.

text.p: Russia's soccer championship reaches a tense climax on Sunday when Spartak Moscow, Alania Vladikavkaz and outsiders Rotor Volgograd bid to clinch the league title.
Alania and Spartak are joint top with 69 points after 33 matches and Rotor, two points behind in third place, have a mathematical chance of overtaking them if both slip up.
If two or all three of the teams finish level on points, an unprecedented play-off or play-offs will be required, regardless of goal difference.

Defending champions Alania have home advantage against seventh-placed Lokomotiv Nizhny Novgorod. Rotor are also at home to struggling Uralmash Yekaterinburg, who will be desperate for a win to avoid relegation.
Spartak, champions three times in a row between 1992 and 1994, have the hardest task with a difficult trip to ninth-placed Zenit St Petersburg.
"It's the match of the season for Spartak. We absolutely have to get three points," said Andrei Tikhonov, Spartak's international midfielder and top goalscorer.
Spartak will need to lift themselves after being ousted from the UEFA Cup by Germany's Hamburg. Spartak drew 2-2 at home on Tuesday but went down 5-2 on aggregate.

Zenit, coached by former Russian national team chief Pavel Sadyrin, beat Spartak 2-0 in Moscow earlier in the season and have the added incentive of a promise of cash from St Petersburg city authorities next season if they finish in the top eight.

Alania are close to repeating their shock success of last season even though Vladikavkaz is only a few kilometres from Chechnya, the North Caucasus region where Russian troops fought separatists for almost 21 months until August 31.
"There are no easy matches now. We'll go for victory and see if luck is with us," Alania coach Valery Gazayev said.

Rotor, who recently led the championship in a season in which the top three have regularly swapped places, are in a gloomy frame of mind after a shock 2-0 defeat last week which all but ended their hopes of a first league title.
Boris Bobrov, the league's general director, said no date had been set for a possible play-off or play-offs.
